<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INTERNATIONAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/17/japan-looks-like-headed-recession?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
For Japan, Third Time's Not the Charm
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="People are seen reflected in a shopping mall mirror at a busy intersection in the shopping district of Harajuku on June 18, 2015 in Tokyo, Japan" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTgxOTcyMjQ4LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Chris McGrath/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After raising a controversial sales tax for the third time last October, Japan posted its <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-third-sales-tax-blunder-must-be-its-final-mistake-11581917580?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">second-worst quarter</a> in a decade. GDP in Q4 2019 fell 6.3% on an <a href="https://www.dallasfed.org/research/basics/annualizing.aspx?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">annualized</a> basis, driven by an 11.5% drop in consumer spending. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Those numbers were bad before the coronavirus hit. </strong>The outbreak, which has infected over 71,000 people, cost Japan critical tourism revenue from January's Lunar New Year holiday and threw supply chains for a loop. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If Japan’s GDP shrinks this quarter (as expected), the world's third-largest economy will be in a recession. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The tax</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Japan introduced the <a href="https://www.nippon.com/en/features/h00013/the-political-history-of-japan%E2%80%99s-consumption-tax.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">consumption tax</a> in 1989, then bumped it to 5% in 1997 and 8% in 2014.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was responsible for that last hike. Arriving in office (for the second time) in 2012, he's improved Japan's deflation, investment, and unemployment levels, but household consumption has remained frustratingly low, growing just 2.6% in real terms over the last 10 years. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Japan's massive debt load (240% of GDP) and social programs won’t pay for themselves, so Abe bumped up the tax again to 10% and paired it with <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/05/world/asia/japan-economy-stimulus-shinzo-abe.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stimulus measures</a> to offset potential negative impacts. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Critics of Abe have plenty of ammunition</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Over the last 25 years, Japan's three worst quarters for household consumption coincided with consumption tax hikes, according to the WSJ.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/90f19130-e8e2-11e9-a240-3b065ef5fc55?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">inflation dipped</a> into the negatives in October, which suggests companies are being more cautious and cutting prices to keep demand up, according to the FT.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> While the Fed and European Central Bank launched stimulus measures last year, the Bank of Japan hung tight. But it's running out of options just as the coronavirus curveball leaves the country on the brink of another downturn.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/17/jeff-bezos-pledges-10-billion-tackling-climate-change?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Feeling the Heat, Bezos Launches Climate Fund
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jeff Bezos" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTU2L2plZmZfYmV6b3MuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>PBS</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As Jeff Bezos showed us yesterday, when you post on the main feed in Insta, you better deliver. The Amazon CEO said he’s launching the <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/B8rWKFnnQ5c/?utm_source=ig_web_button_share_sheet&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bezos Earth Fund</a>⁣, a $10 billion initiative to fund efforts tackling climate change. It's the second <span>largest charitable gift in recent history, <a href="https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/2/17/21141229/jeff-bezos-climate-change-ten-billion?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">per Recode</a>.</span></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“We can save Earth. It’s going to take collective action from big companies, small companies, nation states, global organizations, and individuals,” Bezos wrote. ⁣⁣⁣</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Bezos, the world's richest man, is launching the fund as he and Amazon are under more scrutiny than ever.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Exhibit A: tonight's PBS doc</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/film/amazon-empire/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Amazon Empire: The Rise And Reign Of Jeff Bezos</em></a>, which airs at 9pm ET, does its best to condense an impossibly huge subject into a TV special. It digs into Bezos’s early career, Amazon’s “ruthless” reputation, and the company’s tense relationship with D.C. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line</strong>, <strong style="color:#000">from the show notes: </strong>“Jeff Bezos is not only one of the richest men in the world, he has built a business empire that is without precedent in the history of American capitalism.” The question the documentary asks is, are we okay with that? <strong style="color:#000"></strong></p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MANUFACTURING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/17/chinese-factories-slowly-return-work?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
China Goes Back to Work...Slowly
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="An illustrated gif of a package moving down a factory line" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=447 src="https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1567550239.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="An illustrated gif of a package moving down a factory line" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1567550239.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Chinese factories are starting to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/17/business/china-coronavirus-economy.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">creep back to life</a>. Toyota is back in action as of yesterday, Airbus had a soft opening last week, and GM restarted some operations this weekend. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>But the damage is done. Yesterday, </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/2ed97816c426883a735db996cb1185af?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple said</a></span><span> it doesn't expect to hit revenue guidance for the current quarter, citing iPhone manufacturing disruptions in China.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Chinese factories had been shut down for weeks—first for the Lunar New Year holiday, then as tens of thousands were infected with the coronavirus. China accounts for around 25% of global manufacturing output and plays a role in a dizzying number of supply chains.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But while the world depends on the health of Chinese factories, those factories depend on the health of their workers. Authorities are requiring managers to supply employees with facemasks and <a href="https://apnews.com/085c35be673d2cd3b3bacfe4b82dadbc?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">check them</a> for fevers. It's a delicate balancing act, and many plants remain understaffed.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>if you trust the financial markets, the economic disruption from the coronavirus will only be temporary. Chinese stocks <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/chinese-stocks-recover-from-coronavirus-driven-selloff-11581930971?mod=lead_feature_below_a_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">recovered</a> all of their post-Lunar New Year losses yesterday. </p>

<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F02%2F17%2Fchinese-factories-slowly-return-work" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/17/pier-1-files-chapter-11?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Pier Pressure
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A photo of a Pier 1 store" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTYwL2FfcGhvdG9fb2ZfYV9waWVyXzFfc3RvcmUuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Steve Morgan, Pier 1 Imports sign - Hillsboro, Oregon 2013, CC BY-SA 3.0</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you're looking to buy a home furnishings retailer, one went up for sale yesterday. Pier 1 Imports filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and said it's <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-17/pier-1-imports-begins-voluntary-chapter-11-proceedings?srnd=premium&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">actively looking</a> for potential acquirers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With Pier 1, you'd get a 58-year-old company that…</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Secured $256 million in debtor-in-possession funding</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Is closing up to 450 stores</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Reported nine straight quarters of comparable sales declines</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Drooling at the opportunity? Wait until we tell you about all of its competitors, from TJX's HomeGoods to Wayfair and Walmart. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Pier 1's story is a familiar one to retail experts. It was late to the e-commerce game, has a bloated real estate portfolio, and in 2019 hired a guy the WSJ <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/pier-1-imports-files-for-chapter-11-bankruptcy-11581959763?mod=hp_lead_pos3&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">calls</a> a "retail bankruptcy veteran" as CEO. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Interesting fact: </strong></span><span>Retailers often wait until after the busy holiday season to file for bankruptcy, making January and February popular months for Chapter 11s. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>start preparing your offer now. Qualified bids for Pier 1 will be due around March 23. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENERGY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/17/uae-becomes-first-arab-nation-nuclear-power-plant?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
UAE Goes Nuclear
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A photo of the Barakah nuclear reactor " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTgxOTcxNzk4LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/User:Wikiemirati" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Wikiemirati</a>, <a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Barakah_nuclear_power_plant.jpg" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Barakah nuclear power plant</a>, <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/legalcode" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CC BY-SA 4.0</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Nuclear power is getting its first Arab expansion team. Yesterday, United Arab Emirates regulators handed the Barakah nuclear reactor its operating license, anointing it the <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emirates-nuclearpower/uae-issues-operating-license-for-arab-worlds-first-nuclear-plant-idUSKBN20B0LG?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first nuclear power plant</a> in the Arab world. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It's an exclusive club. </strong>Only 30 countries currently generate nuclear power, and no new country has joined the club since China in 1990. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Building a nuclear power plant </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/17/uae-gets-green-light-to-operate-the-arab-worlds-first-nuclear-power-plant.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">isn't that simple</a></span><span>. Barakah went over budget, faced years of delays, and required a 14,000-page application.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Total financing for the project—a joint venture with Korea Electric Power Corp—came to $24.4 billion. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The UAE isn't facing an energy crunch. In fact, it's the No. 3 producer in OPEC, a tight-knit group of oil exporters. But like its neighbor Saudi Arabia, it's trying to diversify its economy away from oil production and invest in renewables. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the project calls for four reactors in total by 2023. The goal is for these nuclear plants to generate 25% of the UAE's energy requirements.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PODCAST
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Who Broke the Way We Work?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<img alt="Business Casual logo" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc0MzcwMDU5LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Even if you didn’t have work yesterday, chances are you still answered a few emails, checked a few Slacks, and broke into a sweat thinking about all the things you’ve got to catch up on this morning. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But what if work...didn’t have to be like that? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week on Morning Brew’s </strong><strong style="color:#000"><em>Business Casual</em></strong><strong style="color:#000"> podcast</strong>, we examine how work came to rule our lives—and what some in the business world are doing to fix it. Basecamp CEO, remote work enthusiast, and Bezos-approved founder Jason Fried explains why today’s idea of a work/life balance isn’t doing us any favors. Plus…</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>How Silicon Valley’s ideas of “move fast and break things” broke the wrong things</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>How venture capital puts companies in “pressure cookers”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And how tech could change the notion of 9–5</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Listen here:</strong> <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/Fried_apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/fried_spotify?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Spotify</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/Fried_All?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">everywhere else</a></p>
</td>
</tr>

</h3>

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nFor Japan, Third Time's Not the Charm\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"People are seen reflected in a shopping mall mirror at a busy style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eChris McGrath/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter raising a controversial sales tax for the third time last October, Japan posted its \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-third-sales-tax-blunder-must-be-its-final-mistake-11581917580?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esecond-worst quarter\u003c/a\u003e in a decade. GDP in Q4 2019 fell 6.3% on an \u003ca href=\"https://www.dallasfed.org/research/basics/annualizing.aspx?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannualized\u003c/a\u003e basis, driven by an 11.5% drop in consumer spending. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThose numbers were bad before the coronavirus hit. \u003c/strong\u003eThe outbreak, which has infected over 71,000 people, cost Japan critical tourism revenue from January's Lunar New Year holiday and threw supply chains for a loop. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf Japan’s GDP shrinks this quarter (as expected), the world's third-largest economy will be in a recession. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe tax\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJapan introduced the \u003ca href=\"https://www.nippon.com/en/features/h00013/the-political-history-of-japan%E2%80%99s-consumption-tax.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econsumption tax\u003c/a\u003e in 1989, then bumped it to 5% in 1997 and 8% in 2014.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePrime Minister Shinzo Abe was responsible for that last hike. Arriving in office (for the second time) in 2012, he's improved Japan's deflation, investment, and unemployment levels, but household consumption has remained frustratingly low, growing just 2.6% in real terms over the last 10 years. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut Japan's massive debt load (240% of GDP) and social programs won’t pay for themselves, so Abe bumped up the tax again to 10% and paired it with \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/05/world/asia/japan-economy-stimulus-shinzo-abe.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estimulus measures\u003c/a\u003e to offset potential negative impacts. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eCritics of Abe have plenty of ammunition\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOver the last 25 years, Japan's three worst quarters for household consumption coincided with consumption tax hikes, according to the WSJ.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/90f19130-e8e2-11e9-a240-3b065ef5fc55?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einflation dipped\u003c/a\u003e into the negatives in October, which suggests companies are being more cautious and cutting prices to keep demand up, according to the FT.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e While the Fed and European Central Bank launched stimulus measures last year, the Bank of Japan hung tight. But it's running out of options just as the coronavirus curveball leaves the country on the brink of another downturn.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs Jeff Bezos showed us yesterday, when you post on the main feed in Insta, you better deliver. The Amazon CEO said he’s launching the \u003ca href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/B8rWKFnnQ5c/?utm_source=ig_web_button_share_sheet\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBezos Earth Fund\u003c/a\u003e⁣, a $10 billion initiative to fund efforts tackling climate change. It's the second \u003cspan\u003elargest charitable gift in recent history, \u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/2/17/21141229/jeff-bezos-climate-change-ten-billion?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eper Recode\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“We can save Earth. It’s going to take collective action from big companies, small companies, nation states, global organizations, and individuals,” Bezos wrote. ⁣⁣⁣\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBezos, the world's richest man, is launching the fund as he and Amazon are under more scrutiny than ever.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eExhibit A: tonight's PBS doc\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/film/amazon-empire/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAmazon Empire: The Rise And Reign Of Jeff Bezos\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, which airs at 9pm ET, does its best to condense an impossibly huge subject into a TV special. Yesterday, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/2ed97816c426883a735db996cb1185af?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eApple said\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e it doesn't expect to hit revenue guidance for the current quarter, citing iPhone manufacturing disruptions in China.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eChinese factories had been shut down for weeks—first for the Lunar New Year holiday, then as tens of thousands were infected with the coronavirus. China accounts for around 25% of global manufacturing output and plays a role in a dizzying number of supply chains.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut while the world depends on the health of Chinese factories, those factories depend on the health of their workers. width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTYwL2FfcGhvdG9fb2ZfYV9waWVyXzFfc3RvcmUuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eSteve Morgan, Pier 1 Imports sign - Hillsboro, Oregon 2013, CC BY-SA 3.0\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you're looking to buy a home furnishings retailer, one went up for sale yesterday. Pier 1 Imports filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and said it's \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-17/pier-1-imports-begins-voluntary-chapter-11-proceedings?srnd=premium\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eactively looking\u003c/a\u003e for potential acquirers.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith Pier 1, you'd get a 58-year-old company that…\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSecured $256 million in debtor-in-possession funding\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIs closing up to 450 stores\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eReported nine straight quarters of comparable sales declines\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDrooling at the opportunity? Wait until we tell you about all of its competitors, from TJX's HomeGoods to Wayfair and Walmart. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003ePier 1's story is a familiar one to retail experts. It was late to the e-commerce game, has a bloated real estate portfolio, and in 2019 hired a guy the WSJ \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/pier-1-imports-files-for-chapter-11-bankruptcy-11581959763?mod=hp_lead_pos3\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalls\u003c/a\u003e a \"retail bankruptcy veteran\" as CEO. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eInteresting fact: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRetailers often wait until after the busy holiday season to file for bankruptcy, making January and February popular months for Chapter 11s. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003estart preparing your offer now. team. Yesterday, United Arab Emirates regulators handed the Barakah nuclear reactor its operating license, anointing it the \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emirates-nuclearpower/uae-issues-operating-license-for-arab-worlds-first-nuclear-plant-idUSKBN20B0LG?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst nuclear power plant\u003c/a\u003e in the Arab world. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIt's an exclusive club. \u003c/strong\u003eOnly 30 countries currently generate nuclear power, and no new country has joined the club since China in 1990. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBuilding a nuclear power plant \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/17/uae-gets-green-light-to-operate-the-arab-worlds-first-nuclear-power-plant.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eisn't that simple\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Barakah went over budget, faced years of delays, and required a 14,000-page application.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTotal financing for the project—a joint venture with Korea Electric Power Corp—came to $24.4 billion. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe UAE isn't facing an energy crunch. In fact, it's the No. 3 producer in OPEC, a tight-knit group of oil exporters. But like its neighbor Saudi Arabia, it's trying to diversify its economy away from oil production and invest in renewables. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe project calls for four reactors in total by 2023.
